title: Raheem Sterling insists England's "winning mentality" can carry them all the way to Euro 2020 glory
text:

Raheem Sterling admits England are already dreaming about winning Euro 2020 next summer.

England can clinch qualification for the tournament with victory over Czech Republic on Friday night and they then have the prospect of it being a “home tournament” with Group matches and the final stages at Wembley.

Sterling believes England now have a “winning mentality” which can carry them to their first major trophy since the 1966 World Cup.

England forward Sterling said: “Yes, it’s something you think of all the time, especially coming so close in the [FIFA 2018] World Cup and having such a good run as a team.

"I think we’re developing and we’re kind of getting that winning mentality.

(Image: Getty Images)

“The [UEFA] Nations League was a bit disappointing, but we’ve got another chance now and I feel that a lot of the players don’t just want to be involved in tournaments and finish in the quarter-finals and say that was a good run, or the semi-finals.

“You know, a lot of the players, I’d say every single player, and the manager, all want to go into tournaments with the thought of winning it.

“It will be a difficult task but it’s definitely something that we all dream of winning, but there’s only so much you can dream about in the league, but from the first game you’ve got to start doing it on the football field, and that’s scoring more goals than your opponent and conceding less.”

Sterling is used to winning trophies with Manchester City , clinching a domestic Treble last season while the Liverpool contingent won the Champions League.

(Image: Eddie Keogh for The FA/REX)

But Sterling believes the competition for places is the biggest driving force for Gareth Southgate’s squad and that strength in depth brings out the best in the players.

He added: “I’d say momentum is the most important thing, scoring goals but at the same time being able to see games out when it’s not your day.

“You know, there will be games when our attack is not quite up to scratch but we’ve got to grind out a result and wait for a key moment in the game, which will be a set piece, and score that.

"I think little key moments like that are definitely vital for England.

“Being away with the national team is so different; everyone wants to win, everyone wants to. There’s no-one in the squad who’s just happy to be in the squad.

"Everyone wants to play, everyone wants to be in the starting 11 and will be disappointed when they’re not starting.

“So, we have a team of 24, 23 players and everyone wants to play and challenge each other. I think that’s when you know you’ve got a team with the right mentality who want to do well.

"It’s not just the starting 11, it’s the players competing for positions.”
description: The Manchester City flier is adamant the Three Lions are ready to end their 54-year major tournament drought
authors: Eddie Keogh For The Fa Rex
